text: Hello everyone and uh thank you for
taking the time to come to this early
morning session. So briefly about
myself, my name is Tim Durius. I'm a
rendering engineer at Epic Games and
normally I work on things such as single
layer water, the water plugin, sparse
volume textures and other kind of niche
features in a way. Um and last year I
got the opportunity to work on something
really really interesting and that is
the reason we're all here today. namely
first-person rendering or to be more
precise native firstperson rendering.
This is actually a feature that we
already shipped in Fortnite Ballistic
last year also in UEFN as the first
person device and actually excuse me uh
as an experimental feature in Unreal
Engine 5.5.
Um and actually with 5.6 it has now gone
into beta. All right, so let's look at
the agenda for today. So, first off,
we're going to talk about what even is
first person rendering. Then, we're
going to explore the solution space to
all the challenges that it poses. Then,
I'm going to describe how we solved it
in Unreal Engine. And then, I'm going to
give you some uh pointers to how to use
it in practice and how to make the most
of it uh in your project. How to make
the most of it for your project. And
then finally, we have a short
conclusion. And I'm going to try to
leave some time for Q&A. um might be a
bit tight, but I will hang around so you
can feel free to ask me questions
afterwards.
All right, so let's get right into it.
What is first person rendering about?
So, I suspect that most of you probably
played um a first person game before,
most likely a first person shooter. This
is what I'm going to be using as an
example throughout this uh talk, but the
things I'm going to talk about here,
they apply to generally all first person
titles or first person genres maybe. Um,
so this is just the example that I'm
using because that is what I had in
hand. It's also the most common one
probably. So the idea is that we have a
first person perspective and that means
the player sees the world through the
eyes of their player character which
means that they can see their own arms,
the weapon that they're holding and when
they're looking down legs and parts of
the lower torso. And all of this comes
with certain expectations and
challenges. So let's dive into that. So
the biggest and probably like the first
challenge that you will run into is
scene clipping. So first person geometry
should never clip with the scene. This
is an expectation that players have come
to have over the last few decades. I
suppose and I put an example of this on
on these pictures. So the top one is
what you don't want to have and the
bottom one is what players would expect.
They do want to peek around corners
really tightly and also they kind of
have to get really close to walls. We
need to give them that leeway because in
a way players are kind of clumsy. So
what I mean by that is um in real life
when you're navigating your environment
you have a pretty good sense of where
your limbs are in relation to each other
and in space. And we're pretty nimble in
in a certain way when we navigate our
environment. But um a player in a video
game, they need to go by what they see
on screen. And also, if we're being
honest, the controls that they have are
kind of all rough. So, in a way, players
sort of move like a tank. Um so, when
they want to go through a doorway, um we
should give them, you know, some leeway
and you know, maybe close one or two
eyes, um to let them pass through that
doorway, even though their huge sniper
rifle would really block them from going
anywhere. Um, and on top of that,
clipping would just look bad and it
breaks immersion. Um, but something to
really keep in mind here is that what
we're trying to achieve here is
fundamentally non-physical. So the rest
of our renderer is, you know, based on,
you know, a world that makes sense to
some degree. This does not. This makes
no sense whatsoever. Okay, next
challenge. Field of view. For those of
you who might not be familiar with that
term, the field of view essentially
describes the angle of the viewing cone
of the player or the camera in the video
game. And the thing about first person
titles is that players, especially on
PC, often want to have a very high field
of view in first person games, so they
can see as much as possible of their
surroundings, which theoretically gives
them an an advantage. Um, the issue
though is while this might look fine for
the rest of the scene, it usually does
look pretty horrible for first-person
geometry. So, again, I've put an example
here. Um, the top image is um what it
looks like when the scene and the first
person geometry is using the same field
of view. And I like to call this effect
spaghettified. So, essentially the arms
are like way stretched out and the
weapon looks kind of weird. And I'm
fairly sure, I would hope so, at least
you haven't seen this in an actual ship
game. So, what you're usually more
familiar with is the perspective that
you see below. Um, so actually, first
person geometry usually only looks good
at a few specific field of views or like
a narrow range of the field of view
band. So, next time you play um another
first person title that has a slider to
change the field of view, play around
with it and pay attention to it. it will
most likely only change the field of
view of the scene. But if you take
before and after screenshots and compare
them, your first person geometry, so
your hands and your gun will look the
exact same. So they figured it out.
Um, this is also non-physical, but well,
my gut feeling tells me it's not quite
as horrible as the first one, but you
know, it's still it's kind of it doesn't
really make any sense. Um, and it also
um poses questions like if we're
rendering the first person geometry with
a different field of view, essentially
their pixels end up on a different
location on screen. If you compare these
two images and now if the player tries
to reach out to grab something in the
world, how how can you make that
connect? Like that is a challenge. Many
games uh need to get creative when
solving this one. Okay, so let's uh
pause for a moment here and look at how
this is broadly very typically solved.
So, traditionally, the first place the
first person player is just two floating
arms and a gun. That's what games have
been doing for well, probably 20 years
at this point. Um, and it fixes the
problem to some degree um in a very neat
way because um the first person geometry
is disconnected from the world. So, you
can never really touch anything except
for the gun that you have in your hands
and that one is also considered first
person. you do not have legs so you
don't connect uh to the world in that
way. So that means we can just render
the um gun and arms at a different field
of view. And um there are some downsides
of course to this. Well, obviously you
don't have legs and it usually struggles
with uh shadows and reflections. So you
know walking up to a mirror or um
receiving proper shadows, casting
shadows, that sort of thing. It's it's
not the same as the rest of the scene.
But since it's disconnected from the
rest of the scene, you cannot really
tell in most cases that it's getting
different lighting. Okay, challenge
number three. Where are my legs? So,
I've just talked about this. Many games
have shipped with just two floating arms
in a gun. Um, that looks fine. And to be
honest, in most cases, players are not
looking down. Um, but it's the current
year and I think, well, in my opinion at
least, a high quality firstperson
experience should have legs when you
look down.
But uh this is tricky because legs do
connect the player to the world. So we
need to figure out how to solve um
lighting and field of view and anti-
clipping such that still works with the
legs. So that needs special handling.
Okay, next challenge, lighting and
shadows. So first person geometry should
receive the same lighting as the rest of
the scene. So this one might seem like a
bit of an obvious thing, but depending
on how we want to solve the other
challenges, this itself becomes
obviously really challenging. Well,
maybe not obviously, but well, it does
say challenge number four. Okay. Um, it
should also cast and receive shadows.
And again, we cannot have two floating
arms and the gun cast shadow on the
scene. Otherwise, you know, the jig is
up, players can see what's going on, and
we we can't have that. And lastly,
reflections. So, the first person
geometry should properly reflect the
scene, but it should ideally also be
reflected in the scene. So, if you walk
up to a reflective surface or a mirror,
then the player should be able to see
their full third person self in that
mirror. Many play uh games do not have
this for good reasons, but um it would
be nice if we could support this. And
again, they should not see two floating
arms at the gun in the reflection as
that, you know, would totally break
things. Okay, so let's summarize our
first person wish list. So, first off,
we want a solution for clipping and
field of view. So, we can have these um
basic problems solved. Next up, the
player should be able to see their legs.
Um lighting and shadows should all be
consistent. The first person character
should cast shadows onto the scene and
receive shadows from the scene. And
finally, we want reflections to work
properly.
Okay, so at this point, you might be
wondering, wait, what? How come Unreal
doesn't have this already? After all,
Unreal has its roots in well, Unreal,
which is a first person title. So what's
going on here? So actually Unreal Engine
3 had a feature for rendering geometry
in a different layer. Um unfortunately
this was removed in Unreal Engine 4 due
to complexity and um well it's just
plain difficult to make that work with
the F shading. And to be quite honest,
this didn't really solve all of these
challenges anyways. So the system that
I'm going to present today is a big step
up from what Unreal used to have. And
actually this also means that all the
first person titles shipped on Unreal
since we removed this had to implement a
custom solution or except like the scene
clipping and no custom field of view. So
you know people had to get creative and
it's been long overdue that we fixed
this. Okay, let's explore the solution
space.
Okay, so I just said there's like um a
huge number of firstperson games out
there and almost all of them really need
to solve these issues somehow. So you
know just let's let's just take a look
around and see what what you can find on
the market so to speak. Okay. So first
let's take a look at um how we can
represent the first person geometry. So
this is what I would call maybe
headless. I don't know like I came up
with all of these names. There's like no
official uh naming for this but the idea
is fairly simple. So we just you know
chop off the player's head and place a
camera there. Um it's straightforward.
It has uh quite some advantages and
disadvantages. So, one of the advantages
is we can solve lighting and shadows
fairly trivally. We can just render the
full um body into shadow maps, including
the head and um everything just works
because it's essentially the same same
geometry in the same position in space.
Um you get visible legs when you look
down. I mean, it's all there after all.
Um and you don't need to offer separate
animations if you already have third
person animations. Um, but you know, it
doesn't really solve clipping or do
anything for custom field of view. So, I
guess all of this is a bit besides the
point. Um, and also animations might be
a bit too janky in first person. So,
usually what looks good in third person
probably does not look good in first
person. And it's actually kind of
interesting in real life. Um, you know,
we move around a lot, but I suppose our
brain like compensates that and we don't
really notice. But uh in a video game,
people would probably get nauseous. That
said, there are titles that have shipped
with this. Um I think mostly in the
simulation genre. Um so it is also a
valid solution and I guess it does
depend on the content and you can't
tweak things. Okay, so next up, floating
arms. Uh you'll see this is like a
recurring theme here. Um so you know,
it's just two floating arms in the gum.
Um no legs. So geometry is not connected
to the scene. And um that just means we
can render it at a different field of
view and uh use different lighting if we
have to to u you know fix the other
issues. And um there's no visible
mismatches since it's not connected to
the scene in the first place. Then
again, there's usually no shadows.
Ignore that little shadow down there. It
shouldn't be there. Um and it likely
does need special firstperson
animations, but in my opinion, that is
uh well invested time. Okay, so let's
look at the first solution that you
would probably find if you, you know,
start googling for this. So I would call
this one compositing and it's fairly
straightforward. So the idea is we first
render first person geometry into its
own texture and then we just composite
that with the scene. So essentially
separate render target and then just
paste that on top. Um, sounds simple,
but there are some challenges. Like how
do we compute lighting so it matches the
rest of the scene? And like how's that
even supposed to work? Like does it live
in a separate world? And if it lives in
the same world, like how how does that
work? Um, also it costs memory and
performance. Um, it adds quite a bit of
additional complexity because now we
essentially need to duplicate our
rendering pipeline and run everything
twice. Um, and also depending on how you
set things up, if you just copy over the
color, then um, the first person pixels
do not have a representation in the
depth buffer. So, you know, post effects
or anything relying on depth cannot see
the first person geometry. But I suppose
there are ways to fix this. Okay, next
one. Um, like I said, I just came up
with the names myself. I call this one
separate render pass. So uh it's
slightly more involved but not terribly
complicated. So the idea is we first
render the first person geometry and
then we set up the um lighting pipeline
such that scene pixels cannot ever
overwrite a first person pixel. So since
we first rendered the first person
geometry we guarantee that nothing ever
will overwrite those pixels. And the way
we can do that is uh what I would call
depth stencil trickery. So, one of the
most uh most um straightforward ways of
doing that is you just set a stencil bit
when you draw the first person geometry
and then when you render the rest of the
scene into that same texture, you just
check for that stencil bit and if it's
set, you just skip. Um what that gives
you is a depth buffer where firsterson
pixels can essentially cut holes into
the scene geometry or into the depth
buffer. So imagine you're like face up
against the wall and your rifle is
sticking into the wall further away from
the camera than the wall itself. Then
since we had this whole stencil thing,
the wall pixels are kind of closer um
than the pixels of the gun. So what that
means in practice is that things get
really complicated when you come to
transparency and VFX because those you
know we cannot use stencil with them. if
we could like they need to blend against
the scene and if they didn't need to
blend against the scene then they could
be opaque. So um effectively what this
means is when you stick your um gun into
the wall and fire and you would normally
have a muzzle flash effect that muzzle
flash effect will be depth tested away.
Um also uh one issue that we have in
Unreal is stencil is kind of tricky in
Unreal. So many of the bits are already
spoken for and the meaning changes
throughout the throughout the duration
of the frame. And also it's kind of hard
to integrate with manite like it's not
impossible but it's hard to do it in a
way that is still performant. So
might be good for other engines though.
Um yeah. All right. So the next one is
uh well kind of a generic thing. So the
idea is we just use a custom projection
matrix. Um the way that works is we just
have um a separate projection pro
perspective projection matrix with the
field of view that we want to have for
first person geometry and then we can do
some uh depth buffer trickery which I'm
going to go into next um to solve the
clipping issue. So that solves both
field of view and clipping. Um it
doesn't do anything particular for

but you know it could be a start. Um, it

for maintaining a separate set of
matrices. It's not terrible, but it does

what our projection matrix looks like.
And I tried to show this on the right.
So the top one is um essentially what

then essentially we sort of need to

Okay. So depth partitioning this is the

idea is that um we can reserve a range
of the depth buffer for first person

I tried to show this on the right here.
So that that cube is supposed to be

and this does solve clipping. The first

what we can do is we can undo um the

Um all right next one. This one is a

call it scaling. Uh yeah I don't know

in the view space essentially um we are

um and that that blue box around the

we can effectively prevent clipping with
the rest of the scene. Physics takes
care of it for us.
Um, and you might be wondering, how does
that even work? Like, wouldn't it look

there's one exception. Exactly from the

and super close up to the camera. So,
internally, we called it the baby hands

question is like how do we light this?
So we kind of figured out that you can

down geometry. Um cuz usually light

there's an issue with shadows. So first

Okay. So if we look at things scaling

that's you know uniform scaling. It's

the model matrix that transforms from

object was authored in like blender or
something into world space. Then the V
is the view matrix that transforms into
view space which is a space that is
relative to the camera. And then the P
is the perspective projection matrix.
That one achieves the field of view and
essentially makes things that are
further away smaller. You will notice
that I added this underscoref. So that
is supposed to be our first person

Okay. But what we're really looking for
is this matrix T which we can slot in

matrix. And the way we can construct
that one is like this. So first we again

our first person perspective matrix. So
that first part is exactly the same that
we have in the uh first line. And then
we're doing something really
interesting. We're going back from
perspective projection space into view
space but this time using the inverse
scene projection matrix. What that gets
us is a position in view space that is
essentially the delta between the two
field of view projections. And then we
again go back into world space because
that is what we wanted. And uh you know
now the rest of the regular pipeline
which is again view space and then
normal perspective projection space.
This looks all really long and kind of
